Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Controlled Substructure Identification of Tall Building Structures Under Wind Excitation

POR.DRECONTENT:
As buildings age, many structural components start to break down. This causes weak points within the building and if engineers can detect this early, catastrophes can be avoided. This research developed a new technique to use sensors to measure micro-vibrations in the structure caused by wind. The sensor data is analyzed and the weak areas within a structure can be identified well before the structure is at risk of collapse.

This research was selected as an extension of my PhD research on damage detection in earthquake prone areas. By working with the members of the Bridge and Structure Laboratory at the University of Tokyo, I was able to develop new techniques that are appropriate for high wind areas. These researchers are world leaders in wind modeling and were instrumental in the research. Together, we found a new technique to detect weak areas in a building that is vibrating in the wind.

In the future, this technique will be tested with large scale simulations and even wind tunnel tests. Soon thereafter, it will be ready to be used in skyscapers and other tall buildings. In the meantime, my research has been positively effected by this research opportunity in Japan. I met numerous international researchers which formed the basis for several collaborative efforts that are currently in design. I will use this experience to improve our understanding of earthquakes, wind, and structural safety both domestically and abroad.
